importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, and the article reports on the crash at Hong Kong International Airport, with the event occurring early Monday morning local time.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The cargo plane skidded off the runway and crashed into the sea at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, which is the time the aircraft went off course upon arrival from Dubai.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a vehicle it struck and pushed into the water.
The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, with the tail section snapped off and the front section below the cockpit severely damaged.
The four crew members on board were treated at local hospitals and confirmed to be safe; there was no cargo on board.
The aircraft did not transmit any distress signals during approach, and no emergency request was received from the pilots.
The airport suspended operations on its north runway until the aircraft is removed from the sea, though two other runways remain operational and no major flight disruptions are expected.
The flight was operated under an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides extra cargo capacity to major airlines.
More than 200 people, fire engines, and boats were involved in the emergency response.
Hong Kong International Airport, one of the world’s busiest, has a history of rare fatal aviation accidents, such as the 1999 China Airlines crash during a typhoon.

namedEntities.name: Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international airport located on an island about 20 miles west of Hong Kong's Central district.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The incident occurred at HKIA, where the cargo plane skidded off the runway and crashed into the sea, leading to casualties and a major emergency response.

namedEntities.name: Boeing
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The cargo plane involved in the crash was a Boeing aircraft, indicating the type of aircraft used in commercial cargo operations.

namedEntities.name: ACT Airlines
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ACT Airlines operated the cargo plane that crashed and provided extra cargo capacity to major airlines via wet-leasing.

namedEntities.name: Emirates
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The flight had an Emirates flight number, indicating it was operated under Emirates branding, although the aircraft was wet-leased from ACT Airlines.

namedEntities.name: China Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major airline based in Asia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Historically, China Airlines experienced a fatal crash at HKIA in 1999 during a typhoon, providing context about the airport’s safety record.

namedEntities.name: Kai Tak Airport
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The former airport in Kowloon City, Hong Kong.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kai Tak Airport was once considered one of the world’s most difficult airports for landings due to its location in a densely populated area, highlighting the challenges of aviation at Hong Kong’s former site.

namedEntities.name: Steven Yiu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive Director of Airport Operations at HKIA.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided a direct account of the incident, stating that the aircraft collided with a patrol car and pushed it into the sea.

namedEntities.name: Wesley Yung
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Technical chief at Hong Kong’s Civil Aviation Department.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He confirmed that the aircraft did not transmit any distress signals during approach, indicating normal flight behavior until the crash.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) upon arrival from Dubai at around 3:50 a.m. local time, breaking in two and crashing into the sea. The aircraft collided with an airport security patrol vehicle, killing two occupants. Four crew members were injured and taken to hospitals; no cargo was on board. The plane did not transmit distress signals. The airport suspended operations on the north runway, though other runways remain operational. The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines under an Emirates flight number. Despite HKIA's status as one of the world’s busiest airports, such incidents are rare, with a notable past crash in 1999 involving China Airlines.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
